thread.title: Nepal: Fear is crippling tourism

author: eTN Editor
title: Nepal: Fear is crippling tourism
text:
Nepal: Fear is crippling tourism Adv: 
By Anil Mathur, eTN India Correspondent | Jul 09, 2015 Adv: 
INDIA (eTN) - Nepal, the Himalayan nation bordering India, which was hit by a devastating earthquake on April 25, is once again ready to receive tourists from India and other countries. 
This strong message was sought to be conveyed by the Nepal officials and tourism industry leaders who addressed the meeting in New Delhi on July 7 of the Indian Association of Tour Operators. 
Director General of Tourism Tulasi Prasad Gautam and Ashok Pokharel, President, Nepal Association of Tour Operators, led a large delegation from Nepal to India and said that the major tourist places in Nepal were not hit by the quake and the places which were hit have been largely restored. 
Reputed international agencies have testified that most of the places are safe and fit for tourists, said Pokharel, adding that accommodation in the Everest and Anapurana region was mostly fit for being used. 
Krishna Prasad Dhakal, Deputy Head of the Nepal Embassy in India, said that fear was hitting tourism, while there was no cause for this. IATO President Subhash Goyal said that the association will do everything it can to promote tourism to Nepal. 
The IATO meeting also saw Tourism Minister Mahesh Prasad saying that tourism was vital for all aspects of growth. 
Ashwani Lohani, Commissioner of Tourism, Madhya Pradesh, invited the members to come to Indore for the 31st convention from August 20 to 23, 2015. 
IATO and the Association of Tour Operators Andaman signed an MOU to promote tourism to the island.
